question: Question_04_(a)
statement:
Let

\begin{align*}A = \left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
2 & 0 & 0 \\
1 & 0 & -1 \\
-1 & 2 & 3
\end{array} \right]\end{align*} Then is \emph{A} diagonalizable? Explain your
answer.
sols:
A matrix is diagonalizable if you can find a basis of eigenvectors, here
that means we look for three linearly independent eigenvectors.

To find eigenvectors, we first need to find eigenvalues. For this, we
compute the characteristic polynomial:

\begin{align*}
\det(A-\lambda I) &= \left| \begin{array}{ccc}
2-\lambda & 0 & 0 \\
1 & -\lambda & -1 \\
-1 & 2 & 3-\lambda \end{array} \right| \\
&= (2-\lambda)((-\lambda)(3-\lambda) +2) \\
&= (2-\lambda)(\lambda^2-3\lambda+2) \\
&= (2-\lambda)(\lambda-2)(\lambda-1) \\
&= -(\lambda-2)^2(\lambda-1)\end{align*} And so \emph{A} has the eigenvalues 1 and 2. We now employ
two facts about eigenvectors:

\begin{enumerate}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  The eigenvectors of distinct eigenvalues are linearly independent.
\item
  The number of linearly independent eigenvector for a given eigenvalue
  (= dimension of the eigenspace = geometric multiplicity) is between 1
  and the algebraic multiplicity of that eigenvalue.
\end{enumerate}

Recall that the algebraic multiplicity corresponds to the exponent in
the characteristic polynomial:

\begin{align*}\det(A-\lambda I)  = -(\lambda-2)^{\color{red} 2}(\lambda-1)^{\color{blue}1}\end{align*}

means that the algebraic multiplicity of the eigenvalue 2 is two, and of
the eigenvalue 1 is one.

With this we conclude that

\begin{enumerate}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  There is exactly one eigenvector corresponding to the eigenvalue 1,
  and it is linearly independent from any eigenvector corresponding to
  the eigenvalue 2.
\item
  There is either one or two eigenvectors corresponding to the
  eigenvalue 2. We can find out how many by calculating the dimension of
  the eigenspace.
\item
  If the dimension of the eigenspace corresponding to the eigenvector 2
  is two, then there are three linearly independent eigenvectors and
  \emph{A} is diagonalizable. If the dimension is only one, then
  \emph{A} has only two linearly independent eigenvectors and is not
  diagonalizable.
\end{enumerate}

Hence, we only need to find the dimension of that eigenspace. Since that
eigenspace is the nullspace of the matrix \emph{A} - 2\emph{I}, we
simply compute the rank of that matrix:

\begin{align*}
A-2I &= \left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
0 & 0 & 0 \\
1 & -2 & -1 \\
-1 & 2 & 1 \end{array} \right] \\
&\sim \left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
1 & -2 & -1 \\
0 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 0 \end{array} \right] \end{align*} And since the rank is 1 this eigenspace will be of
dimension 2. Therefore matrix \emph{A} is diagonalizable.
hints: What is a condition for a matrix to be diagonalizable?

You need to show that one can find three linearly independent
eigenvectors.
